header.title: The Scroll of Set - Issue Number 20, Volume II-8

central_thesis: This issue of The Scroll of Set functions as an internal communication forum, reflecting on the challenges of member contribution, celebrating individual Setian journeys and leadership roles, and establishing norms for constructive intellectual discourse within the Temple of Set, rather than presenting a new magical system.

structure_content.summary: This piece, written by the editor, humorously expresses the frustration of encouraging member contributions to The Scroll and the effort required to produce it, while also serving as an indirect call for more active participation from Setians.

An autobiographical account of Jinni Bast III°, a member of the Council of Nine, detailing her early life, her discovery of Satanism, her engagement with Anton LaVey, and her subsequent initiation and progression through the ranks of the Temple of Set to become a Priestess and Council member.

This article discusses the dual nature of criticism, distinguishing between its constructive role in correcting misconceptions and fostering new ideas, and its destructive potential as a tool for ridicule. It urges Setians to contribute openly to The Scroll, emphasizing that the publication relies on members being willing to 'think out loud' to achieve synthesis of Setian concepts.

Two evocative poems explore themes of esoteric perception, the nature of an unseen, powerful entity, the journey of self-becoming, and a mystical call to a 'greater place' through companionship and understanding of an 'Essence,' hinting at spiritual evolution and connection to a deeper reality.

key_concepts.definition: The official periodical of the Temple of Set, intended as an internal forum for members to share ideas, experiences, and contribute to the collective understanding of Setian philosophy.

A form of feedback within the Temple of Set's intellectual discourse aimed at correcting mistakes, removing misconceptions, and fostering the development and synthesis of new ideas, as opposed to criticism used for mere ridicule.

While not explicitly named, the underlying Setian philosophy of self-creation and self-evolution ('coming into being') is implicitly presented through Jinni Bast's personal journey of transformation and the poetic themes of becoming all one is meant to be.
A governing body or council within the Temple of Set, membership of which signifies a high level of initiation and leadership.

practical_system.description: This periodical issue does not present a practical magical system or a set of operative rituals. Instead, it functions as an organizational and philosophical support document for the Temple of Set. It encourages active intellectual engagement and personal development aligned with Setian principles, showcases leadership, and provides guidelines for internal discourse, thereby implicitly supporting the broader practical system of the Temple of Set without detailing specific magical operations.

relevant_quotes.text: One of the primary functions of the Scroll is to present new ideas and reactions to them, allowing all Setian concepts to achieve synthesis through a common forum.
The Scroll of Set, not to mention the Temple itself, cannot do its job if Setians are reluctant to think out loud.
Asking merely for all that we are to become all that He is; Showing the path, providing a guide and silently urging with impatience and wonder.
The Darkness becomes our strength - an unbreakable bond between us; And that now-familiar and beloved voice speaks clearly, 'Lo, I pass near to thee; I pass near to thee.'

'Come walk with me again! The planets are your stepping-stones to a greater place; The Earth will fall away For you need not substance nor familiar roots; Your knowledge Understanding Of my Essence shall be nourishment enough.'

critical_analysis.relevance: This issue is highly relevant for understanding the internal dynamics, cultural norms, and communication strategies within the Temple of Set during its formative years (1977). It highlights the organization's emphasis on individual responsibility for self-development, the value of member contribution, and the importance of fostering a supportive yet intellectually rigorous environment for the exploration of esoteric concepts. It provides a rare glimpse into the practical concerns and philosophical underpinnings of an emerging Left Hand Path organization.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience is the membership of the Temple of Set, particularly those at the III° level and above, and aspiring leaders. It also serves as valuable historical and sociological data for researchers interested in contemporary Western Esotericism, occult organizations, and the development of Setian philosophy.
